causes: Dutch expansionist policies in the East Indies
Aceh's strategic position along the Malacca Strait
Dutch desire to control regional trade and weaken Aceh's influence
Acehnese resistance to colonial domination, fueled by Islamic identity
events_leading_up_to_war: British-Dutch Treaty of 1824 recognized Aceh's independence, but Dutch sought to alter this over time
Acehnese diplomatic efforts to secure support from the Ottoman Empire and the United States
Dutch justification for war based on alleged Acehnese piracy and disruption of trade
Dutch invasion of Aceh in 1873, marking the start of the war

result.general: Dutch military victory after prolonged resistance
result.treaty: No formal treaty; Aceh was forcibly incorporated into the Dutch East Indies
result.territorial_changes: Aceh annexed by the Netherlands, becoming part of the Dutch East Indies

Dutch.troops: Approximately 50,000 over the course of the war
Dutch.warships: Several naval vessels used for blockades and coastal bombardments

Acehnese.troops: Tens of thousands of guerrilla fighters at various stages
Acehnese.weapons: Traditional weapons, some firearms, guerrilla tactics

Acehnese.displacement: Large-scale population displacement due to scorched-earth tactics

major_battles.name: First Dutch Invasion of Aceh
major_battles.description: Dutch forces launched a full-scale invasion but suffered heavy losses, including the death of their general. The invasion failed.

major_battles.name: Second Dutch Invasion
major_battles.description: The Dutch took control of the capital, Banda Aceh, but faced continued guerrilla resistance.
major_battles.outcome: Dutch tactical victory, but war continued

major_battles.name: Guerrilla Resistance Phase
major_battles.description: Acehnese guerrilla forces waged a prolonged war of attrition against the Dutch, using ambushes and hit-and-run tactics.

terms: Mass killings and executions of Acehnese leaders
impact: Severe depopulation and destruction of Acehnese society
Aceh remained a center of anti-colonial resistance into the 20th century
Dutch continued to face minor revolts until their departure in 1942

long_term_effects: Aceh retained strong Islamic and anti-colonial identity
Resistance movement influenced later Indonesian independence struggle
Dutch rule in Indonesia increasingly questioned internationally
Aceh remained restive even after Indonesia's independence in 1949

economic: Dutch gained control of Aceh's trade and resources
Destruction of local economies due to prolonged war
political: Strengthened Dutch colonial rule in the East Indies
social: Mass loss of life and cultural upheaval in Aceh
Acehnese nationalism and Islamic identity strengthened
